Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Operator Radiation Exposure in Transcatheter Valve Implantation

Trial_Design.evidence: In this randomised controlled trial, operators wore dosimeters during TAVR-TF (n = 50) and TAVR-AA (n = 31) procedures.

Participants.evidence: TAVR-AA was performed in a hybrid operating room (OR), while TAVR-TF was conducted in either catheterization labs (n = 16) or a hybrid OR (n = 34).

Intervention.evidence: Disposable radiation shielding pads (RADPAD) or a placebo were used in a blinded manner.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate operator radiation exposure during transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) using transfemoral (TF) and alternative access (AA) approaches, and to assess the efficacy of disposable shielding.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was operator radiation exposure, measured in mRad.

Blinding.evidence: Disposable radiation shielding pads (RADPAD) or a placebo were used in a blinded manner.

Number_Randomised.evidence: operators wore dosimeters during TAVR-TF (n = 50) and TAVR-AA (n = 31) procedures.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Operator radiation exposure was significantly higher in TAVR-AA compared to TAVR-TF (median 15.1 mRad [IQR 8.6, 32.4] vs 5.5 mRad [IQR 2.4, 9.8], P < .001).

Harms.evidence: No adverse events related to radiation exposure were reported.
